reviews.text: Definitely recommend this museum if you want to learn more about Catalonia. Was 6 euros and you can easily spend a couple hours here. You follow the history of the region chronologically, and the exhibits are also kid friendly and equally interesting for adults! Most information is in Catalan, Spanish and English, however some of the information about specific artefacts was not in English (but I didn't mind this, you still get the idea). Really informative, and you can end by checking you the beautiful view of the harbor from the roof! You don't need to eat at the restaurant to see it.

This museum covers a lot of Catalonian history.  It was interesting and quite informative.  There were actually "touch and feel" exhibits which kids might like--my twenty something liked them, too.  I thought this was the one with the underground city, but that history museum is in the Gothic Quarter.  I enjoyed both of the history museums.
Do go. Do learn and be educated about not only Catalunya but also the development of humanity. This is a superbly curated museum with very helpful staff.

Rich collection in a beautiful building,  it covers all eras,  it is very interesting for children and nteractive. You are allowed to touch things.  Moderate price,  easy access. Spend some time to enjoy it.

I found the upper floor of the museum particulary interesting as it dealt with the making of modern Barcelona, including the dreadful Civil War where Franco's suppression of Catalunya is within living memory and doubtless fuelling the independence movement.  The cafe terrace on the roof is good and you can view some spectacularly vulger yachts in the harbour.  Not crowded.  It is located at the bottom of Las Ramblas and is free on the first Sunday of the month,

The museum shows the Catalan history through great displays. It is the perfect place to learn about this region and to understand what happened in the past and the real value of Catalan. I really recommend this museum in Barcelona.

For many Europeans it´s hard to understand that a part of Spain don´t want to be Spanish anymore - if you want to understand a little more, go and visit this wonderful museum where the whole historiy is explained. But be aware: If you come with students you have to reserve a speciel hour to visit the place - my students couldn´t go as there were some many other groups who had reserved weeks before. My colleague and I then went to see the museum by ourselves in the afternoon - and spent hours - it´s really a good and very modern exhibtion. The bookshop closed before the museum - take care !

Wasn’t on our original to do list but as were looking for something to do on a morning decided to give it a go and we were not disappointed. There is a lot of information that gives you background to the history of Barcelona and Catalunya. The museum is well laid out and very god value
Huge museum with lots and lots of exhibits and information. The part about Catalonia in the 20th and 21st centuries was my favourite. Great view from the terrace too.

If you have any curiousity at all as to why numbers of Catalans want independence, this museum is a must.  It tells the story of Catalonia from prehistoric times, through to occupation by the Romans, the Visigoths and the Moors, the feudal Catalan counts, the region's stormy and sometimes violent relationship with Castile, and right up to the present day.  It uses a mixture of display boards (in Catalan, Spanish and English), artefacts (both original and reconstructed), and reconstructions of, for example, houses and shops.  There is also a leavening of hands-on exhibits (can you lift the medieval knight's 30 kgs of armour?) to appeal to the young and the young at heart.  The whole thing is clear and beautifully curated.  You can also log on to a website at the museum which gives information about the exhibits in Catalan, Spanish, English and French, with audio read-out if you want it (speakers of other languages are not well catered for).  If you feel in need of a break from history, the roof-top restaurant and bar/snack bar give great views over the harbour, although both are expensive.

We spent a couple of hours at this museum on our return to Barcelona for one day before flying home. It was definitely worth a visit. Amazing preservation of nicest Roman ruins under the city! The lighting Nd setup was well done and we used the audio guise to enhance the experience. Recommended as a to do (probably number 5 or so of top attractions)

Really fabulous displays, very informative and thorough history of Catalonia. A wonderful learning experience to study the history of a region not taught in most American schools. A must see in Barcelona.
Best lection of Calalan history connected with other history events from beginning of human time. Recomend to everyone who want to connect history unerstanding of European history

Museum was well worth visit if interested in Barcelona and Catalonia history.
Roof top bar has great view of marina and city. 
Service in museum was excellent. 
Service in bar not so good. But worth going for views and good cocktails.
Not just frequented by tourists. So a good sign!
It was more expensive than turning up on the day.  There were no queues, no one checked our tickets.  If you want to go ... just turn up.   Don’t bother with this
Everything you do around history and learning the past will be good and well rewarded in the old world.

Full disclosure - i did not visit the museum, i merely walked through it to get to the roof top bar.

Fantastic spot over looking the marina. The atmosphere was chill and wasn't invasive. It is popular though, so you may end up waiting a little for a table. 
It was 14 euros for a Gin & Tonic, which i guess is more than what you would usually pay but it is a very nice spot. The service was good, i don't recall waiting too long for the drinks.
A very interesting museum that explains for different decades the growth of the city and of Catalonia itself.
They have special things. Among them we tasted an assortement of  tomatoes  from the vegetable garden. And recomend the octopus. The service was fine, friendly, attentive and beaming.

The hidden gem of Barcalona - go through the dark museum at night and up the lift to this rooftop bar overlooking the port. VERY reasonable prices for the location (5 euro large beer). You won't regret it.

Can't seem to find the rooftop bar listed separately so I'm writing this review on the main museum link but I've got to tell you all not about the museum but the AMAZING rooftop bar on the top! Wonderful views of the mariner and great cocktails. Feels very special and unique walking through an empty museum to get there but this all adds to the experience. A real find!

As others have said detailed but dry and not all displays are covered in English. Cheap entry but not a place for young children.
The best bit is going to the roof, walk past the (empty) restaurant onto the rooftop cocktail bar - amazing views over the marina!

The recreated scenes were very beautiful and informative. I learned a lot about the history of Barcelona. Do reserve at least 3 hours to go through this museum as it is quite big. One complaint would be that some of it is not translated, which makes it difficult to understand for those who don't speak Catalan.
If you want to understand better a Catalan culture, this is the place to go. Well explained historical information all the way from the stone age until today.
While the experience was very educational, it felt dry and boring and it was hard to tell if some of the exhibits where actual samples or replicas.  The price was very reasonable.

The museum of Catalan history is large. Seniors with ID receive a discount. For your general admission, you can ask for headphones with a standard quarter inch jack. This will not work on the latest iPhones which use the lightning plug. However, there were no other visitors to the museum and I just used the audio speaker on my iPhone. Wi-Fi is free and you can access the audio guide online using the information provided on the second floor. The audio guide on your phone provides descriptions of selected exhibits in the museum. There is a good, good explanation for each and easy to understand.

There are extensive exhibits providing the history of this area. The rest of Spain is pretty much ignored. The museum is done very well. Signs provide explanations at every step in English.

The problem, however, was that there was no air conditioning on the 2nd and 3rd floors. With an outside temperature of 30°C (87°F), the inside of the museum was very, very hot and uncomfortable. I think this would not be a good place to bring children.

If you like this review or any of the photos, please could you give me a thumbs up? You may wish to check out my reviews of other sites to see in Barcelona, as well as another Spanish cities, and also Lisbon, Sintra, Porto, and cities in southeast Asia, South America, Australia and New Zealand.

This is a very well organized museum with wonderfully organized and educational displays going from prehistory up to the 18th century.  We spent a whole day here, breaking for lunch outside in the sun and then going back for the afternoon (you can leave and return the same day with the ticket).  This would also be an outstanding rainy-day activity.

This museum takes you back in the history of catalunia from the ancient times until now.
It is very interesting with good excibits and you can learn and see a lot.
It needs a better orientation and sequence within the excibits as it was a little confusing some times.
The museum is wheelchair accessible.
The store was closed even if it was a normal morning.

this is a great background to the region but takes time to go around

if you're into the history it's a must if you don't have much time don't worry

The full size galley display is worth the visit in itself. The ship is stunning. I loved the audio guide as it automatically took to the era wherever you were standing. The history is only of Catalonia so you don’t get a sense of the maritime history of Spain which was a pity.

Well worth a visit !
The museum was very well laid out.It is also very informative.Children would enjoy the interactive exhibits.It is a nice place to wander around and relax.There are nice views from the rooftop.Make sure to take some photos.Long live the people of Catalunya.
Your history is very interesting .I could see parallels with our history.
It is inexpensive to visit.The restaurant on the top level is a bit overpriced.

Definitely worth the money you will spend for the tickets to enter. It was all very interesting. It’s also interactive so if you’re with children, it’s a great way for them to learn about history while having fun!

Well worth the investment of a couple of hours to get a totally different perspective on the people of Catalunya. Great museum packed with information, beautifully laid out is a treat. Under 16’s get in free so no worries about your teenagers lack of interest in the thought of a museum until they get there. Don’t forget to check out the added bonus of the roof terrace views of Barcelona.

I visited during the late afternoon and pretty much had the place to myself. I came looking for information on bandits, pirates and the Guerra dels Segadors and I wasn't disappointed! There were many other treasures in the museum besides and I'd go back with broader interests another day. The MUHBA on paper seems like the obvious choice, but the Museu d'Historia de Catalunya gives a more rounded overview of the history of the city and the surrounding region through time, leaving almost nothing out. A real winner.

Man-oh-man was this place packed with history!  I learned a ton from 5000 BCE to nearly  the present.  The museum is well-curated and worth a visit.  Nice roof-top bar, too, and close to Barcalonetta Beach.  Don't confuse this place with the Barcelona history museum, which is focused mainly on the Roman ruins.

The most impressive part of the experience of this museum is its interactive displays and artefacts. I learned a lot about Catalan history on my way around the exhibits and could easily have spent longer than two hours exploring everything. Great for anyone trying to understand the culture and history of Catalonia and Barcelona during a stay in the city.

This museum is beautifully laid out in this old building, depicting through the ages the history of Catalonia.  I went to this museum while wandering around the city, and for such a small price I wouldn't see why you wouldn't want to check this out.  

The museum itself wasn't all that crowded, and I was able to walk at my leisure around the various displays and exhibits. It was like walking through a time machine.  I had learned very much about this unique region (or I should say country) going back through its ancient roots, through the middle ages to the civil war and the present.  I myself was surprised something this fantastic wasn't incredibly crowded.

I did not get to enjoy the rooftop terrace and restaurant because I was meeting up with a friend else where.  I will definitely do this museum again in the future, and will be recommending it to friends who travel to this city.
Great rooftop terrace with stunning views of the port and the city! and the most delicious sangria with cava complements the beauty of the moment !!)

This was a really interesting history lesson. It covers from early Catalan settlements right through to the modern day. There's quite a lot to see and at a very good price. We got a discount as had the Barcelona card but even without it the cost would be around €7 per person.

We pre-purchased tickets for 6.50 euros but there is no need as few people were around. It complimented much of what we had been told by guides and locals about the proud history and fierce independence desire of Catalonians.
English was included in most descriptions or an English guide page was available for permanent and temporary displays. Our time was limited as we returned early by public transport from Barcelona, but we will return at a future date.
Overall an excellent museum with super friendly staff.

We just returned from five days in Barcelona and find it our duty to inform the traveling public that the restaurant and roof-top bar is nothing short of fantastic.  It is our most favorite bar in Barcelona, with a view of the marina, the city and Montjuric.  The Museum of History for Catalunya is in it's self a activity that you should not miss in visiting Barcelona.  Do yourself a favor and go there some afternoon and enjoy the view from the roof top.  Never have seen a line to get in.

We visited this on a wet afternoon on the basic tour for 4.50 euros each, and found it well laid out with plenty of interesting exhibits showing the development of Catalonia throughout history , we probably spent about 2 to 3 hours just on the 2nd and 3rd floors running through the whole history of Catalonia.
There were quite a lot of English translations which helped but more again woukd bevefen more helpful.
Really good place to visit to understand the history of the country and region. Only 4.50€ to get in and we spent a good few hours there.

General history museum, good for children as well. Most of the interesting pictures/maps are only in Spanish / Catalonia thus I was missing some parts of the story. In general its worth to go inside and a have a quick look.
An easy museum to follow and very interesting. Would recommend visiting the top floor terrace as it has amazing views over the harbour.
We enjoyed visiting this museum. So much history of Catalunya. Very clean and affordable. They also have frequent special exhibitions.

This is the place to visit if you want to know more about Catalonia and its history.
located by the port in an old building with a wonderful cafe on the top floor.
If you are a history buff this museum also includes artifacts and films of what affected Catalonia over the last thousand years. Going back to Franco's dictatorship and further back to the cavemen.
Certainly if you have time it is a treasure trove of information

This was my first visit to this museum and I was not sure what to expect.  The entrance fee was only Euro 2 because some of the exhibits were being updated.  One floor had more than enough to see.  There were a lot of exhibits on the history of Catalonia going back thousands of years.  Most exhibits had good English translations.  I spent well over an hour here and could have spent more time.  I was impressed with the museum and the way the history was presented.

As other reviewers have pointed out, this museum is short on actual historical artefacts but if you follow the route you get an interesting story of the history of the Catalonia. However, there was nothing that could not be read in a book. There is a distinct whiff of separatist propaganda in the way that the informIon is presented. Lots of examples showing how the people of Catalonia and Barcelona have been badly treated by the rest of Spain or Europe over the years but little or no examples of the benefits from being part of Spain. I expect that school trips to this museum will further the separatist cause in the years to come. It is striking though just how much the people of this region have done and how forward thinking they were in their attitudes to having a fair society. Not sure that the museum was our best choice though.
Very enjoyable exhibit of the Catalunyan history. It was even fun for the children . They have lots of things on display
If you want to know Catalunya history you should definitely visit this museum, to see what was happening there years before us. I recommend it.

Given the difficulties in Catalonia, we spent an afternoon informing ourselves about the area's history. The museum starts with an archaeological perspective, and continues with a political and cultural exposition. It ends with the demise of the Franco regime and the rise of the modern technological era, but does not go into the politics of separation and the relationship with Madrid. However, it is apparent that like much of Europe, Spain's districts evolved separately, and national identity is fragile.

The exhibition is on two floors, with a beautiful cafe and observation deck on the roof. Four euro entry fee; three if you are a senior or retired.

This was a beautiful museum with detailed dioramas and historical facts of the Catalan people. Some of the facts were slim or not as detailed (for example, according to the museum the Catholic bishops did not really agree with the Spanish Inquisition. What?) However the pieces were interactive and great if you had children with you. I was grateful to have a deeper understanding of the history as we were there while the state was in great upheaval over the vote of Catalonian independance.

As I am a big history fan this was a must see in Barcelona especially given the current political circumstances (my visit was right after Catalunya held the independence referendum). What I liked about the museum is that it has a very modern feel to it, trying to tell the (hi)story through pictures, maps, dioramas and actual artifacts. The building housing it is also an old dockyard building that was repaired and repurposed. 

What I didn't particularly like about the museum though is that it didn't convey the history of the Catalunyan people but the history of the space that is called Catalunya. Or in other words, the story of the population inhabiting Catalunya over the centuries and not that of the Catalunyan people. I don't feel like I know a lot more about the Catalunyan people after visiting the museum than I knew before.

On the topic of the restaurant, I can't say anything about the eating experience because we didn't stay. However, if you do go, note that the restaurant has several different sections: the room you enter is for drinks and deserts, as well as the terrace; the second room is where you can eat the regular courses and you have a wide selection of wines available.

I was most disappointed in that this ended up being a two floor walking tour of mostly dioramas and reproductions. It's inexpensive and not time consuming so if you are along the waterfront walking to Barceloneta pop by. If you don't have a lot of time, I would not add this to your to do list.

If you are interested in finding out about Catalan history this is a must.
Spent a thoroughly enjoyable 2 1/2 hours here on a Sunday morning and virtually had the place to myself.
At €4.50 was a bargain and though a lot of the actual exhibit info is In Spanish the narrative is in English so it’s not to hard to follow.
Don’t expect to see many photos of Franco. While he is referred to a lot 
The only pictures I saw were announcing his death and dead in his coffin !

Whilst the lower floors house artistic display areas, make you way to the top where there is a bar and restaurant.  This has wonderful views (from the outside terrace) over the port where the rich and famous moor their super yachts.

I visited this museum on a recent trip to Barcelona and I wasn't disappointed at all
Although there is no audio hand sets available, the museum's displays are explained in many languages
The exhibits range from prehistoric times ( which I have to say didn't interest me too much) to the development and expansion of the city of Barcelona and the Catalan hinterland!
Who knew that catalunya had a large Mediterranean empire which included Sardinia, Sicily and huge parts of the southern Italian peninsula ( in.my ignorance, not me!)
After a good hour and a half viewing the exhibits, I needed refreshments and on the upper level of the museum is an excellent bar/cafeteria which is open to the outside with fantastic views of the docks and the visiting cruise ships!
All this for a very reasonable €4.50 admission fee made this a very pleasant way to spend a few hours!!👍👍👍

This museum was a very nice surprise for me. Founded in 1996 and located in the port, this museum shows the growth of a nation from the early ages to present. This museum if very interactive- you can sit on a horse scupture or ride a tram. You hear authentic speeches from the speakers, see really interesting stuff about the formation of a proud Catalan nation.

Having been to Barcelona before and done the obvious attractions, on a baking hot day this museum fit the bill!
My background is being a big kid who loved history with a degree in archeology and history.....and I loved this museum and would have loved it even more when I was 12 years old!
The museum itself is set on an attractive marina with plenty to see and do close by; boat trips, cable car, shopping.
The period of history covered goes from "cave men" to the present day and uses lots of techniques to bring history alive and to get children and adults to interract and experience the past.
I was concerned that the history of Catalonia might overwhelm everything, but the common themes of human history, particularly in Europe, come through strongly, making it relevant to everybody.
The building is beautifully air-conditionned for hot days an we broke off in the medieval period to go to the roof terrace where the restaurant is.Fantastic view from the terrace and a chilled glass of white wine and nuts for 5 euro; a perfect break before going back into history.
We paid 4.5 e each as we didn't go into the special exhibits but there are discounts, fantastic value.

We 'popped' into this place as we were just passing really - wow are we glad we did! 

It is exactly what the name implies, a museum of the history of Catalonia. It's hands on and interactive. The exhibits are written in English too - which is ideal for those of us who have only a splattering of Spanish and even less Catalan. It takes you through a time journey of the history of the (occupied?) area with particular reference to the growth of Barcelona. We were there for a good two hours.

This museum is best suited for adults and older teens as working your way through the history is certainly heightened through the associated texts. Quite an emotional journey.

This museum takes visitors from prehistoric times to the modern day. Exhibits were well laid out with plenty of information and although they covered a huge timescale, it was arranged in such a way that there was not too much to take in.

Given where Barcelona is, there were really good exhibits detailing the development of seafaring

A fantastically curated museum of the Catalonian history. We visited this site late in our stay in Barcelona, and finally heloed us understand so much about the history of Barcelona, but particluarly the politics of Catalonia and its unique background.
This museum has a rather interesting collection of exhibits from pre-18th century to the modern day and must-see whilst visiting the city. They have information in Spanish, Catalan and English

the museum is in the port, near the beach
the ticket is 7 euro 
this museum represent the catalunya history 
worth seeing
Not a flashy museum, but offers a good way to gain some history and context for the region. Entry fee is only a few Euros.
The museum has an excellent collection of exhibits with very good information about the history of the region.  Explanations are in Spanish, Catalan and English.

I only had an hour and a half spare to visit this museum and I really would love to back with double the time! So much interesting information starting from the stone age through to the 21st century. You get a great insight into the history and culture of Catalunya. I felt rushed with my time constraints and didnt get to read all the information I would have loved to. I didnt manage to see the rooftop terrace either, sadly. For the price, it is definitely worth the value. I only had to pay €3.50 as a under 25, and it's only a euro more if you not eligble for a concession. Very interactive too, with lots for younger people to admire or those not that interested in history.

We spent a good two hours here and it was well worth the investment of time.  The various displays take you on the journey from prehistoric times through to modern.   Very accessible from both a physical and intellectual perspective, the museum  takes you on a journey from  Stone Age, Romans etc. through to the terrible civil war under Franco and various other wars/developments between them.  The displays are excellent and good for children and adults alike with many recreations and models, many of which are hands on experience.  No audio guides but the English signage (as well as Spanish (of course) and French are very good - fairly succinct but with enough information. The building is brilliant too!  A nice cool, educational activity to get you away from the sun for a bit.  Left me with a much better understanding of why Catalonia is very distinct from the rest of Spain and dare I say, makes me appreciate the secessionist feeling.

What a gem. Didn't look in the Museo, just took the lift to the top floor and went out to the rooftop terrace. 

There is a Restuarant up there, but we just found nice seats and had drinks. 

Views are amazing, and it was quiet as I don't think many know about this little gem.

This museum presents the complex history of the Catalan people, and by and large does so beautifully. It cannot be adequately appreciated with a mere two hour visit, but any length of visit is better than none. There is a really good restaurant (the 1881) and terrace on the top floor.

This museum is really worth the time, if only for the Roman ruins in the basement.  It's difficult to grasp the scale of these Mostly Roman remains, but they are much larger than the other floors of the museum.  I found the laundry and cloth-dying facilities to be the most interesting. This must have been a very important site between the vast amount of clothing treated and fish dried and wine made.  Fascinating!
wait a few weeks till the whole museo is open to the public.(april)it was otherwise interesting in a new cinema way.really weird exhibits but thought proving.

A visit to the museum d'historia de catalunya can be done with young children and is really worth the trip. The prices are relatively low and the exhibition is very interactive, which makes it attractive to visti with children. I learned a lot. The temporary exhibition of the Knight Templars is really worth the visit as well.

This museum is on the marina and is fabulous.  Right now, they have a complete display of the Knights Templar.  We have been there countless times but mostly for a different reason.  They have a fantastic bar and restaurant on the top with a view to die for.  We were just in Barcelona for five days and walked to the museum three times.  You get a view of the city, especially the view of the marina and Montjuric.  A glass or two of wine will cure anyone's day and rest those tired feet from walking.  If you have the time, I guarantee you that you will enjoy what you experience with both the museum and the rooftop bar.  The museum is good for children but not sure of the bar and restaurant.

I was eager to visit this museum due to my interest in the Catalan separatist movement and language.  The two main exhibits feature the history of Catalunya, stretching from when people first lived in the region to the modern day.  There is an overwhelming amount of information, but the museum does an excellent job of using a variety of mediums and interactive features: you can step inside model structures, climb on a model Catalan war horse, and even try on traditional Catalan armor.  The main exhibits have text in Catalan, Spanish, and English; minor exhibits are in Catalan with a pamphlet that contains the translations.  The admission price is cheap (4,50 euros) and there were far fewer tourists than at other attractions.  I would suggest combining this museum with a trip to the beaches of Barceloneta, to give yourself a break from the crowds and the sun.  If you are interested in history and politics, this museum is a must see.

If you have time, you must visit this museum. Really it's not so perfect museaum - but if you have time, you can go it. Price of tickets it's so cheep (in Barcelona price) - just go, see some historical facts.

This museum is worth the time visiting. Everything is neatly presented. History is so interesting like that. You can enjoy riders models, typical houses, nice ruins and artifacts. Do not miss playing with the stones or admiring the vegetables square. Indeed a nice museum with a view overlooking the port. Too bad third floor is closed.

Would not recommend there are much better places to go. When we arrived we where told the best floors where not open. One floor was purely in Spanish so I couldn't understand anything very very disappointing

We went here on a wet day and thoroughly enjoyed the experience - as museums go this is definitely up market - the displays are arranged so that you walk through time from prehistoric to the present - makes you very aware of the strong Catalonian culture.
There is a very good restaurant on the top floor but we had great difficulty in trying to comunicate with staff as to exactly what was on offer and finished up just having a cup of coffee - hopefully you will have better luck !
